segments.text: this is May the 3rd 1986 I'm going to make another attempt at re-taping the
years of my life I've made two or three swings at it now but invariably
something goes wrong had I get nowhere with it so now I have the all the various
pieces of tape numbered and there's going to be about two hours of recording
so as I go along there'll be errors and omissions and there'll be blank spaces
etc but just bear with me in the long run we'll hope you'll get a
pretty good picture of what LHA went through in his
life.
85 years or going on to 85 years of life so right now I'm going to start
back when I was a boy and we left the state of Iowa and then from there just a
running story of what I remember the highlights that I remember they're not
necessarily in good chronological order but
you know it's a struggle.
I think you'll be able to follow the story.
Forgive me for all the errors, omissions, etc.
So right now we'll turn back
and start from about as far back as I can remember.
You'll note a great change in voice from time to time.
This goes back five or six years
from when I first started on this,
and you'll find times when my voice is foggy and cold.
Five years older, your voice gets a different pitch to it.
So you'll understand what it's all about, I'm sure.
So we'll just turn back now and start taping.
From the mic, voice comes out clearer on the replay.
I'm going to do some experimenting.
My first experience at speaking,
speaking into a mic.
I'm going to do some experimenting,
and I've been asked to...
I've been asked by my family to give a history of my life,
and I'll do so.
Whatever comes out must be.
So we'll let it go at that.
In 2007, when I was eight years old,
and we moved up,
I came to Canada from that bridge $25 a year.
All right, now I'll add a few words while I'm trying to get the tapes lined up again.
This is something to try to make a continuous story out of these bits and pieces, so now
I'll start the tape rolling again.
I'm still having trouble.
I'm still having trouble, but I'll get her in time sooner or later.
You'll hear some repeating in the background.
Now the tape cut off.
I can't just...
I can't just tell where it's going to start in, because when I go in on the tape, I find
out I start talking about something else, so I'll finish this story off.
Laurie didn't know what to do, so I got some of the neighbors in and we cut his 40 or 50
acres of oats, which was flat on the ground, we put it up into stacks, and that took us
a few days.
And when that was finished, I went into south, into Nebraska.
Where I had a cousin that was farming.
And I helped them with the harvest, and that's where I found out what real heat is.
It's never been hot for me any place since.
There, it never cooled off at night, it just stayed about 90, 92 degrees day and night.
And I helped them with their harvest, and then I headed north, and I think somewhere
along here we'll cut back.
Okay.
Back in, and I'll pick up when I head back up into Dakota.
So right now I'll turn the other tape on and see what comes out of it, and try to patch
it up.
This is Janie.
Janie had a new baby.
Her first...
After spending 10 days there, she's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
She's gone.
Big stuff here, but I think I'm on the right track now.
I'll go back when I finish thrashing in Frederick and then head up north.
35 days of thrashing, but I think it took us about two months to get there.
And I started, didn't know what I was going to do, so I started north.
I got up as far as Minot.
When I got to Minot, I thought I'd look for a job, and I'm intersecting here.
You might get a job around here.
That's your power company.
Yeah, sure, you can get a position.
You said come to work on the morning.
Well, I'm around there on Saturday and Sunday, and I got looking around,
and I thought, boy, you're extending yourself quite a bit here.
You walk right up in here, and there's a really well high voltage in here,
and I knew something about working high voltage, but not too much experience on it.
Well, I got cold feet, and I never showed up for work.
I had up to.
I was lying about 50 miles, and here's a small crew, power crew, working around the world.
Plus top, top, you know, got tops to the floor, and got a job.
I put on my headline, and he said, like, do you want to come back to the head office in Canberra
and see if you can still hire me?
I'll call them and tell them you're coming home.
So I went up.
Oh, yeah, for sure.
You're going to work tomorrow morning, 79 cents an hour.
Well, immediately, I got to do the headline on that job.
They didn't have anybody there that had the experience that I had of it,
because they used to say cut the mustard, and I got along very good.
I've gone over this, and I've got a tape that already has this information on it.
I'm going to stop now.
This is a continuous tape, where I think I had someone on another tape,
and they got mixed up.
But I'm taking the years, and they've come along now.
And I worked with that out for a long winter.
We went to Canberra, and we went off to Portland, and then the east and west of us.
We had about 150 miles of line, and we had what they called the flying squad.
And there was trouble when we were there, night or day.
It didn't make any difference to me after that.
And I worked until April.
And the immigration one day said, here, you can't help in this country.
You're a Canadian, and you're going to work for me.
Pack it up.
Well, I hadn't told them, but when I sent the phone before,
another one to get off of the phone to the Mac and I,
then we would take the phone over and it was good.
It was an inventory of everything that we saw, all the machinery, all the price on it.
We would pay for it as we go along.
So I had to leave it, you know, the tape, and go back up again.
It was valid, and then it didn't make any headsets on my part,
because the way it was going to go down was wrong, I was doing.
So right now, I'm going to stop for a while, and I'll play it back and see if I can find that other part.
But I think I, you know, that tape that Joe and I went to pass the paint,
I'm trying to put it in the proper chronological order so that it takes year after year if you remember wrong.
You know, after the first half of the game, I'm going to go back and watch it again.
And I was just like, you know, I'm just gonna try this again.
It's been a long time since I did it like that.
But yeah, I'm going to give it a shot.
So you don't learn a lot.
If you're not familiar with the game, you're gonna realize that you're still playing it,
and you're not even going to remember it for a long time.
And that's why it takes so long.
So I'm just going to keep it.
You know, we're still going to look at it.
I'm going to wait for an end.
And so I'm going to make sure there's no more start.
I'm going to go back to this game.
Now that I'm lined up, there's a bunch of wires to be done in that.
So I stand up and walk in there.
Wires come through.
So I remember that I finished and went back up to Gull Lake.
I must move around the lake so there should be wiring to be done in Tompkins.
And I moved back to Tompkins.
There you could get room and board.
I gave back up.
By this time, Jack Dyer was getting kind of tired of running the power.
He was too small for a hit.
And he was at a financial, a different company.
He wasn't doing a very big job running the plant.
It was a diesel plant.
He was adding a lot of power outages in the lab.
So one day I said to him, you're dissatisfied here.
I said, you'd like to get out of here?
I said, I'll take over.
I'll buy you out of here.
Kind of a deal we got.
I had a deal that I would give him all the debts.
I gave him my car and I gave him some cash.
I got it.
He said, I'll go for that.
So I said to the general manager, and that's what I told him about this deal.
Why the hell?
He said, we'll give you the money.
If you want to buy him out, we're not happy with the way he's running the thing anyway.
It wasn't a matter of any amount of money.
I remember I borrowed $600 off the money.
And they stayed with me.
Jack Dyer, when he left Tompkins, he went up to Winnipeg Oasis and organized the starting
of a power plant in Winnipeg Oasis.
Well, he got himself into it.
He got himself into it.
He got the franchise, but then he bogged down right then and there, and he hollered to
me for help.
So I couldn't see where I could help him any.
So I turned the whole issue over to the Dominion Electric, the old power company in Estevan.
And they took over, and he headed for British Columbia, where he spent the rest of his days.
So we'll go on taping again about Winnipeg.
And I'll tell you a story.
John Dyer's so old that I don't know how it came to be that I didn't think that I could
ever get anything done.
It seemed to me he must be depressed.
I don't know why.
But I don't know how.
But I don't know how stupid I was at the time.
And I do know he's still in the home.
I don't know how I got on with him, but I don't know how I got away with it.
So, um, I think people, uh, you know, it's...
But it seems to me that now, this is where everything stops again.
It seems to me right now, it seems to me that I'm in a position where I'm right now.
My mind is like this, don't you see it?
I'm a thousand friends, right?
I'm a fucking loner.
what contracting was like
for the next
18 years
I'll need to be on the right
frame of mind
so with that I'm going to say
goodnight and the date
right now is May the 5th
so I've been
monkeying around for 5 years on this thing
and I haven't come up with anything
very interesting as I
see it and going over it
however we'll
finish it out and give you
a run down on what it was like to be
contracting
this is May the
8th
I don't know if I feel like this morning or not
but I'll make an attempt at
first off I want to say
things were pretty well modeled
up on my tapes
having spoken
into them over a period
of 5 years
and then the kids would get into them
and
some of it would get erased
and
all the way along
it may be hard for you to
follow this story
as it was unfolding
but I just
want to say that it would be
awfully hard to sit down and just
give the history over
an 18
year, 20 years
virtually
I started working on power in 1927
and
and then I worked until just
about the end of 45
for various companies
and through all that I was gaining experience
the biggest thing was handling men
after the first two years that I was
in the electrical business
I was always in charge of men
and that's the big thing when you're
contracting as you depend on your men doing the work. You don't do it yourself.
You have to organize your men and have them working for you and not against you.
And during the years that I worked for the power company, you always had, oh, you had difficulties.
Guys get hard to handle and they buck you a little bit.
And you always, just one thing you had to do, and that's plow them under and keep on moving ahead.
You never looked back. If you had any labor problems, you waded through them and kept on going.
So to get back to when I started out from my day off, that's where I started building.
I didn't have any equipment.
First thing I did was...
I went to a dealer in Estevan, and he had a half-ton truck there.
And trucks were hard to come by at that time.
This truck had about 60,000 miles on it.
It was in pretty bad shape.
But I had to have a half-ton truck, and it was the only one available.
So I virtually took it from him.
I said, I'm going to have that truck, and you can't sell it to anybody else.
I happened to know the dealer very well.
To start, I had a half-ton truck.
Then I rented a man with a truck when I started dismantling airports.
And then I got word that there was some military trucks being sold in Regina.
In fact, the Power Corporation tipped us off to that.
So I came up and I bought an old gun carrier, a great big awkward thing.
It was built for pulling a gun around the country.
And what they called another was a 1500 weight.
It was about a two-ton truck, equipped for battlefield work.
So I took those trucks and revamped them.
Took them down to Midale, and my brother ran a little garage there.
He was able to do welding.
And between the two of us, we got the cutting torches going.
And we got them...
Made something that we...
Made something that would start to function.
There was no steel in the country.
There wasn't.
You couldn't buy anything after the war.
And so I made a wooden derrick tripod on the back of this Army truck.
We had no digging equipment.
Just dug holes by hand.
And I was fortunate enough to get ahold of a couple of experienced diggers.
And they would...
They would dig all the holes we needed for a small outfit.
And a little later, I found out they had another two-ton truck in Regina.
The military was selling off.
I got these trucks for virtually nothing.
I got the Army trucks at about $350 apiece, and they were in mint condition.
And then I bought this other truck.
I think I paid $1100 for it.
And it was virtually like a new truck.
So I had pretty good equipment to start with.
Just the three trucks.
And these Army trucks were open.
They didn't have cabs on them.
So you had to put up with that.
Tough weather.
You were sitting out in the open.
Well, then I finished that job dismantling those airports.
That was one hell of a job.
We uncovered miles and miles of cable that had been buried about two feet underground.
We were supposed to take it up without damaging it.
Well, I tried every method there was of uncovering that cable.
From hand digging right up to getting craters and scraping it out until you got it.
But no way could you go and excavate a half a mile of cable without getting some damage in it.
Scraping it and digging it, even when you're digging by hand.
But you'd rather shovel into it occasionally.
So they told us, take it out as best we could.
And we still had to go through the process of making the trench and pulling the cable out and then filling the trench in.
I could never figure out how three men, three different contractors, could sit down and figure out how you dismantled those two airports.
The overhead lines, underground lines, and everything.
And then use all the usable material.
To build a power line, as I said, from Halbright to Midale to the Cone.
And in the three months, there were four bids.
In the four bids, there was only a thousand dollars difference from high to low.
I happened to be the lowest.
It went all the way from, my bid was $10,500 and the highest bid was $11,500.
But it was almost unbelievable to think that four men could sit down.
This was something that none of them had ever done before.
Or none of us had ever done before.
But we come in that close, that's within 10%.
Which is considered pretty close bidding at any time.
Well I worked in, I finished up in Midale on that project about the end of November.
Then the Power Commission had some work they wanted done up on the north suburb,
what they called North Regina.
Everything north of the sea and tracks.
So I come up and I worked on it through December and January.
Just had a small crew I think, four men or so.
And then after that we went to Saskatoon and did a similar job.
This was for wartime housing.
This was an experience now.
We were digging through frost.
Anywhere up to four or five foot of frost.
But somehow, well in Saskatoon it was in sandy ground you couldn't dig.
So I had to put fire, burn the frost out.
And it all worked out pretty good.
You just did what you had to do and that was it.
Then I came back and I did some work in the town of Davidson.
For the old Dominion Electric Company.
They were still functioning.
And then I went back to Estevan and just sat in quiet until the spring years came up.
And I got a, the first job was from Wavering to Radville.
Which was a nice job and it was an early spring.
We were working on that early in April.
And from there on you just kept on moving ahead.
When I got that job finished they had a bunch of farms around.
Farms around Wavering.
I did those.
Then I went back to Estevan and started building the big high voltage line.
And that was something else too.
There you got, everything was so heavy and big.
And we had never dealt with the cross arms and insulators and poles.
All the poles were forty feet or more.
The cross arms were four by sixes to ten feet long.
And you had to handle all that heavy stuff.
I still don't know how I was able to make a dollar on the job but I did.
I worked all summer.
Besides running out and doing other odd jobs.
That came up from time to time.
And I finished that job on the eleventh day of December.
We had all the wires dropped.
It was heavy wire.
That was a new experience too.
And then I folded up for the winter.
Now I'll relate what I did for help for men.
I got a hold of a fellow.
He's a few years older than myself and had been a lineman.
And he's uneducated.
He could hardly write his own name.
But he's a good worker.
Good honor.
on the last tape, I started telling you what I had for a crew of men to start with. I started
out about Jack Gardner. He's the first fellow I hired. And so I picked up help, young kids
out of school and one thing or another. We're just out staking line and getting material
out. And then later on I rounded up some fellows from Regina here that were experienced
hole diggers. Two of them in particular were professionals. So we started digging the holes
and what have you, and then we, oh yeah, we had to get machinery then to set these poles.
This was the biggest poles that have ever been set in this province. So I had the old
army truck.
It was a derrick made for it, a 25-foot derrick. And we could handle the poles quite nicely.
Once in a while we'd get a heavy one that'd give us some trouble. Well, anyway, in the
meantime I picked up Art Miller. He was just a young fellow out of the army looking for
a job. He was handy at driving trucks, really good with trucks. So that gave me the nucleus
of an outfit.
It was really good. We started setting poles, dropping the poles in the holes and hand tamping.
Have five and six men tamping and two men shoveling. And we'd set about 25 poles a
day, maybe 30 on a good day. And I worked that crew up. By the time I'd finished the
Stoughton job, I had 25, 30 men working for me. And again, I can't get a lot of work for
me.
no one with experience. Until I come to String on the Wire, then I picked up a couple of
fellows that had climbed poles in the Army. That gave me three or four climbers, and with
that we were able to get along. Everything was new. You had to figure out everything
for yourself. No one had ever had the experience of doing a job of stringing a line under the
cross arms. I'll come back to that again. Everybody wondered, how can you string wire
and when the cross arms are on a slant and you can't lay the wire on them? Well, I went
to Winnipeg. I figured out if I got some hay pulleys, about four-inch pulleys, big enough
to take a three-quarter-inch rope. I went to Winnipeg and I went to Ashdown Hardware
and I asked the guy, have you got any wooden hay pulleys? Just the bare pulley I want.
He said, no. I said, no. I said, no. I said, no. I said, no. I said, no. I said, no.
He said, yeah. I said, how many? He looked up his inventory. He had 250. I said, I'll
take them all. The guy looked at me like he was out of my tree. What are you going to
do with 250 wooden pulleys? Oh, I said, I've got a job for them. Don't worry. I'm not buying
them just for fun. However, we designed hangers for these pulleys. They worked out 100%. Today,
they use a pulley to do the same job. Of course, the conductors are heavier, but the pulleys
they use nowadays cost you probably $100, $150 a piece. Those cost me about 35 cents a piece,
plus the labor of assembly. Anyway, that wound up the spouting job. I finished that, as I
remember, right on December the 9th. Then we folded up for the winter. I'll start out and go a year
by year, where we worked, and what we did, sort of run over. There would be so much detail,
too, if I went into detail, of what happened. All the men I went through, and the men I
trained, it would take hours and hours to tell it all. You got to be in the mood for talking.
When you start telling stories about things that happened or, I don't want to call them
stories, especially when you're writing about a  that was as bad as a sea once or here.
things that happened 40 years ago so we'll just wind her up for now I'm going
to listen to Brian Mulroney I listen to Brian and he didn't have much to say
talking on trade with the United States but he talked a lot but he didn't say
much put it that way I'm sitting outside right now it's 88 degrees out here
so on Tuesday afternoon May the 17th June the 17th June the 17th yeah so I
don't know what it's going to be like out here the wind is blowing there may
be some roaring in the mic on kind of a wind I'll just take a shot of this and
see what's happening now lay it back now and see what this sounds like I played
it back
and it sounded all right there's no interference from the wind so I'll go
on talking about 1947 now 1947 my first job was building a line from
Weyburn to Radville and picking up the village of Trossachs on the way
there's an early break up in the spring and we've got an early start after we
finished that job we did about 20 farms just north of Weyburn
and from there I got a job building a line from Dinsmoor to Eston and up from
Elrose to Rosetown that was about 110 miles of line including about 10 towns
and villages that all need a new distribution so we got into that oh I
would say about
mid-June when we started on that job. Anyway, in the meantime, there had been a reunion
organized with a family to meet down at M's place in Oregon. And I didn't know what to
do. I had so damn much work ahead of me. So I happened to be going through Moose Jaw.
My old bank manager from Estevan, Bill Mullins, was the manager in Moose Jaw. So I stopped
in to say hello to him. And of course, the conversation, I told him how much work I had
ahead of me and that there was this reunion coming up where I was to meet eight of my
brothers and three sisters. And I didn't know whether I should leave my job and go down
there or what.
He said, Linda, he said, if I had eight brothers to meet, I'd leave any kind of a job to go
down there to the reunion. He said, the job would go along for two weeks. They'll never
miss you. I said, what difference it would make? He said, you'll never miss.
So we went to the reunion, and it turned out to be a very good trip. But then Ethel and
Phyllis and I went down in one car.
had a new car at that time so we had a really a nice trip we're gone two weeks
and back to the job up at Elrose and no more than got that job on their way
when the superintendent come along and said they had a job running from
Kenora, Saskatchewan up to Priestville and over to Norquay that was about 60 or
70 miles a line took in one two three four five pounds to build it and god
there's no way that I could see that I could handle it and Ted Durnan was
after me they had to get this done sort of a political thing and so funny I made
a deal with him but if he give me his boring machine rented me his boring
machine
to dig all the holes and set the poles I figured I could rustle up the help to
complete the job by the end of the year so I had the job yet the Rosetown Elrose
pretty well underway and Art Miller was able to take over it so I went to Kenora
and start that job again without any help just got my brother Zip to come out
help stake line I that's the first thing you have to
do is take a line and then we hired some local guys there to haul out the
poles and I got a couple of guys to start putting on the cross arms and when
we got the thing laid out ready to go then the power sent up their boring
machine and we went ahead and it was easy to organize a tamping crew you
could get almost any farm labor to work on that job well we got all the pole
set by about oh I'd say we had the pole setting done by about the end of
October in the towns and on the high line there was an awful lot of bush to
cut up in that country I had to hire men with axes to go in and slash a 25 foot
swath through sometimes a quarter mile of solid trees all the trees up to five
six inches in diameter
and that all had to be piled and put out of the way then I then I was jockeying
back and forth between that job and the one over at dens we're trying to get
them both cleaned up before winter and time is running out on both ends so
finally I went over to Dins to host town alros and stayed on that job to push the
wire string they weren't going as fast as they should and we had to get
somebody
in the towns and I sub sublet some of that to local guys that could climb poles
and then I when I left the Kenora job left Jack Jack Gardner in charge well
Jack was the first guy ever hired I think I mentioned before a hell of a
good man but he if you gave him more than two helpers he big he became
confused and he would do all the work and the guys would all stand there and
watch it but I left Jack there he used to start string and wire now he knew all
about string and wire I came back on the job about the Oh about the 20th of
November my god he only had three miles of wire strung well I shouldn't say
that about six miles of wire strung he had been fiddling away for ten days
well I got the god darned mad I went out there and
I
he had a crew of 13 men I went out there and the first guy I'd see that
didn't have something definite to do I said here finished tonight I paired the
crew down to eight men and then we started stringing three miles of wire
every day got organized and really got home well I finished that job hooked up
the last time the day before Christmas well oh yeah it was a weekend came in
there and and I wanted my crew to work on Sunday that we could get everything
spinners today got into beer parlors Saturday and heightened good Sunday
morning you couldn't get any of them out well that's Jack Gardner and myself and
to Brown one vote paw exchange we went out and we didn't all work on the Sunday
and the whole band outfit would you and we kept the the town phone at the last
town, the Sturgis. And during that toll, they had an old, broken-down plant in Sturgis.
He said, you've got to get Sturgis going before you come back in for this. So I worked
all Sunday, and about Sunday night, about 11 o'clock, I got in the car and headed for
Regina. Well, that was about a four-hour drive. Anyway, I got home about 3 o'clock in the
morning. The heater on my car failed during the way in, so I had to drive in in a cold
car. I got mad at the crew. Payday came in, and I said, I'm not paying you guys until
Payday, and we'll be in Regina on that day. So after work on that day, they all laid around
the hotel all day Sunday. Caught the train Monday, got in here Monday, yeah, late Monday
night.
I went down to the station and met them and gave them their paychecks. Monday was Payday.
I laughed at them. I said, you guys were so smart. You missed a day's work, and now you
came in a day late for pay. I said, let that be a lesson to you for the future. Well, I
don't know if it taught them anything. Most of those fellows were come and go.
Well, that wound up our season.
We're 1947. Oh, yes, the Elwood job, they didn't get it quite completed. They were
still finishing things up there in January, and then we shut down until spring.
48, I have to stop and think. In 1948, where did we start? In 1948. I really have to scratch
my head to see where we started.
In 1948, oh, I think, 48, yeah. I didn't get in on the early bidding. That's right.
I lost out on all the jobs. And finally, they came along and they had a job out north of
Swift Currents, a system to put there. And I got going on that about in June. Oh, yeah,
I went and built a line to Cypress Park. That's where I started, from Maple Creek.
Maple Creek to Cypress Park, and then went north of town to Mendham and Leader up in
there, and we were building in a bunch of farms and whatnot. Then come back down and
worked around Swift Currents, did a bunch of Mennonite settlements there, and then down
and put a line from Vanguard to Anroid.
And after that, we had 200 farms to go down at Oxbow. That was the first year we got a
big group of farms. And we had that all finished and had a full season, a good season. Made
good money that year. The weather was good. Everything went fine. And we finished all
our worlds by Christmastime.
Then I come to the city. In the city, there's...
The head guy for the city knew me, and he said they had some poles to set in the city.
So I started setting poles in the city, working by the hour, just so much an hour for men
and equipment. And the first thing I knew, I had half a dozen men going all winter. I
never stopped. And that was the start of a 10-year stint with the city of Regina. And
they asked me for a price for rental of the farm.
They asked me for a price for rental of the equipment and wages. So I gave them rental
rates on the equipment and wages plus 10% onto the payroll. And that was it. That went
on for 10 years without any... I just wrote them, submitted them a letter, a proposal
that I would work for this, and it just kept going and going as wages went up while I charged
them the most.
So I paid them more wages. But the equipment rental, I never changed it in the 10 years.
That's... I was an inflation fighter. And it was a good deal for me because we always
left our poorest equipment in town here because there wasn't that much for it to do. It was
standing around mostly. Boring machines bore an average of about 8 or 10 holes a day. We're
out in the country, they had to bore anywhere 50, 60, 70 or 80 holes a day. Well, that was
in 1948. And in 49, I went to... Oh yeah, I got the piece of high voltage line, the
72,000 from Kalali that's up near Melville up to Yorkton. I moved in on it just about...
just before harvest, I got in on it. Previous to that, in 49, I can't recollect where we
were working.
But nevertheless, we were busy.
We had some project somewhere, and I had a pretty good crew organized. Then we went
in to do that line up from Yorkton to Melville and down to Kalali, another 18 miles. And that
had to be completed by wintertime. Well, everything went fine. We got the poles up, and we got
about half of the wires strung when it came into the first part of December.
And it stormed, and the snow kept piling in. I built a snow pile in front of my big
army truck, and we'd open up a road, and the next day it would blow in again. We kept
that up one week. We opened the road three times and never put a truck over it. Well,
we were virtually stalled. It kept on snowing and storming. So the Power Corporation said,
Well, we're not ready to use that line anyway. We haven't got the transformers or anything.
So I shut her down and held a string, and then went back up and finished it. That was
a spring of 50. Finished the wire string and some substations in Yorkton and Melville.
And then I went down, and I built 18 miles of line from Stockholm to Esterhazy.
After, we're talking 1949, yeah. Oh, yeah, then we had a bunch of farms to do in 49.
That was another thing that was just coming on stream was farm electrification. So we
got some farm jobs, units of 40 or 50 farms to a unit. We did probably 100 farms that
year, and then shut down for the winter again.
And then 50, I started out.
Yeah.
Built a line from Yorkton to Theodore. From there, moved down to, oh, I forgot to tell
you, in 49. Yeah, after we finished that line, then I got a job 30 miles from Yorkton to
Kenora. That was a good straightforward job. We did that up in a hurry, and then out of
work by the end of October.
So I got a job up in Alberta. Went up to Alberta, that's right. Built in a bunch of
farms up around Lloydminster and Beggarville. Maybe did about 70 or 80 farms up in there.
And stayed there until the end of the season. We wound up by Christmas time. Shut her down
for the winter. That was in 49, yeah.
Then in 50, I started out.
Yeah.
Built that line from Yorkton to Theodore. And from there, Lampman to Bean Faith. That
was another 18 miles. From there, down to Shawnevant to East End. That was 30 miles.
And then after that, came in and went from Walmart to Kipling. That was about 60 miles.
So we had, pretty well had a full season and a good season.
I'd made good money and was satisfied to quit when Ted Durnan come along and said,
S. Branders is in trouble with a line down at Ogham in the Cinnaboy country. He's bit
off more than he can chew, and I want you to go down there and help him out. Well, he
said, come on down and look at it. So I got in the car and went down there. And he went
in the Branders trailer, and he was in there three hours.
Arguing with him, and he wanted me to give him a hand on that line to get, because it
had to be done before winter setting. And I'm sitting out in the car, and Durnan's in
there arguing why he was going to take some of it away and give it to me. Me and another
contractor, we were going to set the poles jointly, and then we'd string the wire and
head.
And I said, oh, Branders got mad at me over that one. He blamed me for the whole thing.
And I said, you better find out the facts. I said, how I fought against that. I said,
I had finished a good season, and now Durnan puts the gun to my head and says, you've got
to come out and do that. And I'm commissioning you to do it. You can't say no.
Well, then when we finished that, we went outside of Regina here, just south of Regina,
and did a bunch of farms, maybe about 15 or 20 farms just south of Regina. So we were
going until Christmas time, and then shut down for the winter again. I said, that was
in50. Yeah, then 51, then I got a whole bunch of line. I had about 300 miles
of cross-arm line to build, besides all kinds of farms.
That was in the...
That was in the Ogama-Bangloff Viceroy, down the Rock Glen, Coronac, all in through that
country. Up north, from Kyle to Elrose, and we did about 50 farms up in there, plus seven
or eight towns. Big season that was in 51. 52 was a short season. We, there again, we
didn't start very early, didn't get any work, but always had this crew in the city,
kept my, my basic crew. I could always work them in the city here, never out of work.
That was in 52. And then the farms started picking up. Yeah, we were doing farm projects
all over the place. Maybe did 250 or 300 farms that year. That's 52. Now, I'll just slow
down for a minute here, take a rest.
That's over.
Now we're into 53. 53 was mostly all rural farms. We did about 385 or 90 farms that year.
And we'd had a well-organized operation by this time on the farms. You went out and you
did an average of five miles of line every day. That meant five farms. It meant, it involved
setting about 75 or 80 farms.
75 or 80 poles. And about, that would, 75 or 80 poles would involve about 30 anchors.
And of course, the transformers and everything on them. We had to complete the operation
ready to throw on the switch, which we usually did before we left. And that was in 53. 53
is a good, good year, all the way around. Again, we were still operating in town here.
All the time. The city was expanding. We built all the pole lines in Regina from Campion
College South and every suburb that went in after that. We did all the pole lines on them.
Had, that was a sort of a bread and butter thing. That's 53. I just finished. Okay, 54.
More farms. All the way from, you can say from Maple Creek.
To the west, to, well, we never got as far as the Manitoba border. About Kipling to the
east. And everything always south of the valley. South of the Saskatchewan River and the Coppell
Valley. It was 54. We did about 450 farms. And 55, well, we did some towns and villages
in that too. 55 was more farms again. Then we went up to about 450 farms. And that was
475 farms. And this was all on the set price. The price had been established back in, when,
50, 48 or 50, somewhere in there. It had been established. So much a pole, so much an axon
set. And so much a transformer. Just the three items is all you had to bid on. And that covered
everything. You had to do your own bushing and, and hauling your material and everything.
Well, 55, another big run. We went right up to Aquitaine.
And we went right up till Christmas time. Had snow, about six inches of snow, but the
weather was beautiful. Right up till Christmas time. We wound up, again, 56 more farms. And
it went up to about 450 farms in 56. And occasionally there would come a chunk of high voltage line
in with it. And 57, now the farm operation.
The big units of 40 and 50 farms were pretty well all done. We're doing scattered filling.
And I'll tape six and I just finished saying that we were
57 we were filling in farms it I set up three three-man crews and each one was on their own
They'd haul their poles take their line all their poles
Set the poles string the wire and and connect them
hot ready to go and
then
Well, we did pretty well. We had a nice turn over that here

Five sets of blueprints so that everybody working on the job had a blueprint knew

I had a pretty fair season turned over a profit

I knew what my costs were and I stayed with it

Johnson and ourselves jointly bid on a piece of high voltage line from

in it but was always a big job and river crossing was always a big job it

and after it was finished again that was going around doing odds and ends nothing
the farm electrification by this time was pretty well finished up
it was pretty well finished up
So you didn't go out and do these projects with 40 and 50 farms all of yours.
You had to be mobile and scattered all over the place.
That was 61 and 62 was about the same thing again.
And 63, trying to think, in 63 as the later years come in it's harder for me to remember
what the hell we were doing.
However, by this time we're finished in the city here.
This is petered out.
But there were other things showing up.
Oh yes, the potash mine out here at Kalium, just out of Regina, we got all their work
no matter what they had to do.
They called us in.
Not only on building it, but on design, you know what they said, they didn't have engineers
that were familiar with line work at all, so you got in on the design end of it.
And we, oh yeah, potash mines were coming in and we did quite a lot of work around the
potash mines, running in lines here and there for the potash mines.
That was 63 and 64.
And 65 was my last year.
We got a big project out at Swift College.
We had a very big project in the
city at the time.
Oh, yeah.
I remember.
We had a big project out in the city at the time.
I think maybe the biggest job in dollars and cents that I had ever undertaken.
And then there was a lot of extras came in.
price that everybody said what a hell of a price you got for that well it started

and not lose money but that's what can happen with weather we are rained out

what is it this is the 21st Year now
they've never been out of work I suppose
in the years since the big rock in the
that aren't from the outfit, I never saw his books and never asked him. But judging

And the boys got in on that and I'm sure come out with some nice profits.
However, that's all beside the point. I never regretted having stepped out when

themselves.
And they're
right. I said, look, I think I'm going to be more contracting than ever, and how

And I got out and I wouldn't be alive today if I'd of stayed in there and tried

died of a heart attack just when things were really going good
you

and I don't know I never dig into it I I always figured it's none of my business

saying goes so on the basis of that I'm going to
set her off right now and rolled its back and see what I said I'll use up the

This is July the 21st, 1986. Ben and Leslie were here from June the 27th and just left yesterday, so I put the taping aside while they were here. I didn't want to get things mixed up any worse than what I have them.
And we enjoyed having them at any rate. They're a good company. They had a lot of fun entertaining themselves out in the pool.
Now I'll go back and give you a few things about my life in the electrical field. It was a hectic time. Saw it all grow from year to year, something new.
Every day, you might say, was different.
No two days alike. Never went to work one day, but I was looking forward to the challenge of the day that might come up, and you never knew what might happen.
My years with the companies in the States, where I worked for three different companies, a great experience working with different people, different foremen.
I had about five or six foremen in those two years, and you learn something from each of them.
And so it was a great experience.
So when my day came to take charge, you try to put into effect the good things, the good points that they had.
And I think it probably helped me a lot in my years of handling men.
That was the biggest thing about contracting, was having your men work for you, whether you were there or not.
They liked you. They liked your attitude.
And what have you.
And they worked.
And that's where you got production.
Production worked into dollars and cents.
When I had 40, 50 men working for me, they all called me by my first name.
I didn't want to be Mr. Achen amongst them.
I just lended to them.
And I think that goes a long ways.
You can do it in a small outfit.
You can't do it in a big outfit.
If you get big, then you lose contact with the people that are actually making you the money, the guys that are doing the work.
Well, if you look at my whole career, it was a pretty hectic one.
I started out digging holes, and from there worked up to being a lineman.
And I got to be a professional lineman, a hotline.
There was nothing I couldn't do.
And then into service, or into running a crew.
That was always an important job, to be the foreman on the crew.
And then from there, I went into service work.
I learned how to read meters and how to serve customers.
Along with that, the years in Estevan were really good educational years.
You had to deal with absolutely everything.
I got acquainted with transformers.
We used to rewind our own transformers, repair our own transformers,
which not many men in the business that had the experience that I had had that opportunity.
You got to be a lineman.
That's all you knew, was to be a lineman.
You didn't know anything about transformers or instruments.
Or switchboards, or power plants, or anything.
I had gone through all of this in my years in Estevan.
When I left Estevan, I could have written steam papers.
I knew enough about a steam plant, having been associated with one.
A small outfit again, where when there was trouble, you went down and helped out.
You talked to people.
You got knowledgeable about a steam plant.
Then from that, I went in and I...
operated a diesel plant.
Well, my knowledge in a diesel plant, it was only a one-cylinder engine,
but if you got a six-cylinder engine, it's the same thing, only six times as big.
That's all.
I was in the instrument end.
I could calibrate meters.
I could calibrate switchboard instruments.
I knew all about a switchboard and the workings of it in a power plant.
And all knowledge that you gathered,
you put on the back shelf, and maybe someday you would use it.
And I did, all through the years that I was contracting.
Things turned up to where I could...
where I might even be called in to say,
we've got a problem here.
Can you help us?
And many times, the power people called me in,
and they wouldn't have anybody in the area that was capable of diagnosing a trouble or something.
Those are some of the benefits you got through your wide experience in the business.
Yeah, when you're a serviceman, you had to collect money.
You had to take care of complaints.
You had to do everything.
You got to know...
I had 1,200 customers in Estevan,
and I knew every one of them, and they all knew me.
And in the minefields, got a great knowledge of mining,
both underground and strip mining.
Having served the field for seven years, I was in there,
and it was a hectic life, yeah.
You were on call 30 days a month and 24 hours a day.
You were never paid overtime or anything,
but you were proud as hell that you had a job,
and you knew you could do it.
And when the whistle blew, you went out and answered the call
and didn't sit back and figure,
well, how many hours can I get out of this or anything?
You'd go out and find the trouble,
prepare and get back home, get to bed,
finish your sleep so that you could go to work in the morning.
And that's the way it went from one thing to the other.
I think I related earlier
that I had started doing some inside wiring
way back in 1931,
at the time I built the power system into the village of Midale.
Well, later on then,
things got slack and I continued to work.
And I kept on wiring and wiring,
and finally the wiring inspector said,
why don't you write your journeyman's paper?
So I wrote my journeyman's paper,
and I think I related that earlier.
I was a darn tickled when I got it
because I didn't think I made the exams.
I still carry it today.
And while I really never did much,
really never did much wiring,
there wasn't anything about it that I didn't know
or couldn't sit down and figure out.
And it was something to have that journeyman's paper
in your hip pocket.
The one I have now will run until,
I think it's 1990,
before it expires.
I probably won't be around here.
And the company still keeps me on,
Art Miller's company still keeps me on pay
on the small retainer
because I have that journeyman's paper
and some of the work that they run into
from time to time.
They're supposed to have a journeyman electrician
on the job.
Whether he does any work or not,
that's another thing.
So therefore they keep me available
in case something turns up
where they need the journeyman,
and I'm there.
And now, all very interesting,
you know, to be able to walk in
and see an electrical layout,
know what it's all about.
Not a puzzle or anything.
To the average layman it is,
but it's just as simple as ABC
when you have the principles of it out there.
As far as being a technician is concerned,
you give me this little tape recorder here
and I can't even tell you
what makes it work.
Or telephones or anything.
That was completely out of my line.
The radio was out of my line.
But my life was
get the electricity
from the generator
to the output where it was going to be used.
That was always the big thing.
That's what I specialized in.
I'm glad it's all over
in the electrical field.
I got to be pretty well known
in Saskatchewan.
And now,
I'm one of the older guys in the businesses.
I doubt if there's maybe
two or three fellows in the whole province
of my age that are still living,
that have gone through the business
from one end to the other
or for a period of 35, 40 years.
So I would say to anyone,
it's an exciting life.
Service is what you're in.
Service is what you're selling.
When I was a contractor,
I was selling service.
And I still say,
like George Jenny,
the fellow that worked for me said,
if I had a son,
I'd want him to go and work
for an outfit just like yours.
He said, not too big,
where you get to know everything
about everything.
He said, the knowledge I got there
and the 20 years I worked there,
he said, are just unbelievable.
He had worked from a boy
on the end of a digging bar
up to becoming a journeyman lineman.
And a real good one.
And then he had saved his money
and when he got enough money
to buy a farm,
he,
bought the farm and said,
now I'm going to semi-retire.
And that's what he's doing,
really enjoying life.
I don't know if I mentioned
anywhere along,
the money out of this business.
When I started working
in Worthington, Iowa,
we were working nine hours a day
and I got 35 cents an hour.
Paid my own room and board,
drove a car,
Model T Ford coupe.
The farm came along one day
after I'd been there
for about three weeks.
He said, I like the way you work.
He said, I put in an application
for a raise to 40 cents an hour
and the head office turned it down.
And,
but he said,
I'm going to plug your time enough
to bring it up to 40 cents an hour.
That's when I was a groundman,
digging holes
and doing anything on the ground.
And then when I got to be a lineman,
I didn't stay the same,
but I was only there
for about a month and I left.
I think I told you earlier in the story
when I quit in Nebraska
and went up to work for my brother,
Laurie,
who was sick
at Sioux Falls, South Dakota.
Then when I started work the next time,
I was up at near Aberdeen,
South Dakota.
And I started as a second class lineman.
I was getting 45 cents an hour.
And I had had to return
to the field,
then I had to give my classes
for a year,
but I never got paid,
anything in the first year.
I knew it was a great loss
for the class
because it didn't earn me any money.
How many times I had to work
for my brother,
Laurie,
who was sick
at Sioux Falls,
South Dakota.
And when I started working
the next time,
I was up at,
near Aberdeen,
South Dakota.
And,
I started as a second class lineman.
I was getting 45 cents an hour.
getting 45 cents an hour. And they paid our room and board up to $3 a day. Well, you could
live on $3 a day quite handy in those days. So now I was getting, there was no income
tax deductions or anything at that time. I was getting 45 cents an hour, and I went through
two different foremen with the same crew. The first one died, and the second one was
transferred. And the third one was a younger man, and he took a liking to him. And he'd
come along one day, and he said, you're only getting 45 cents an hour. He said, I'm going
to put you up to 50 cents an hour. That's the first class lineman's wages. He said,
you're doing as much work as any of the other fellows. He said, you ever work hotline? I
said, no. Well, he said, I'll teach you a little bit about it. So he started wearing
rubber gloves now, and then he'd take me out to cut in transformers.
So you familiarize yourself with protecting yourself is the big thing when you're working
around hot wires. And then from there, when I went up to Kenmer, North Dakota, that was
a year later. There I got 78 cents an hour, but I had to pay my own room and board. Then
when I came up to Canada, which was the next year, there I got $0.08.
$0.82 an hour, I think it was, and paid my own room and board. And from there on, things
went bad. And it came back where a lineman was getting $0.50 an hour again instead of
$0.82. So I worked in the summer of 1934, 1935, part of 1933, at $0.50 an hour and paid
my own room and board. It didn't cost you much for room and board. You could keep
most places for $1, $1.25 a day. Some places, they'd even go to a private home. They'd even
do your laundry for you. So it was all very relative. And when I started operating the
power plant, I was getting $75 a month. Then when I, when they closed down that plant,
which I related to earlier, and I went back to the Dominion Electric power, there I was
getting $130 a month.
I paid my own keep, but again, room and board for $1 a day. In fact, I was staying at Phyllis'
folks' place, and that's where I got room and board and laundry for $1 a day. And as
wages went up then, after I was married, that was about three years later, I got a $10 raise.
That was my first raise in three years. I got a $10 a month raise, and then I got a
$10 a month raise. And then I got a $10 a month raise, and then I got a $10 a month raise.
And then, of course, you paid an extra $5 a month, room and board. Groceries were going
up and what have you. So it was all very relative. Well, when I left there, then I started contracting.
I didn't take any steady wage out of the company. I just threw out money as I wanted to, but
you didn't need much to live on. Maybe, oh, $200, $300 a month. And then, you know, I
got a $200, $300 a month. And then I got a $200, $300 a month. And then I got a $200,
$300 a month. And then I got a $200, $300 a month. And then I got a $200, $300 a month.
And then I got a $200, $300 a month. And then I got a $200, $300 a month. Well, you
know, the first thing I did was when I incorporated that in 1953, I didn't know what wages I should
draw, so I asked the auditors, what wages should I take out of this? Well, the rate
your company is going, you should have $1,000 a month. I'm coming to the end of this tape,
so I'm just going to wind it up, and this will be the end of the history of LHA. I thank
